attributes.comment:
My husband and I are a young (28 yrs old) couple and have been unable to
conceive biological children thus far. We have embraced the idea of adoption and
are in the process of adopting our first child from Vietnam. This is a process that
millions never put themselves into, but a process that through love and
commitment to our child, we have chosen to pursue. When we began looking into
adoption, many agencies offer these "solutions" for funding the process, which
can easily be between $20,000 and $40,000: get home equity loans, get advances
on credit cards, hold fundraisers, talk to people about making donations. In a
world where we are inundated with credit cards, debt consolidations, credit
counselors, etc....why on Earth should we be put into this position because we
are adopting? Honestly, how many people giving birth are asked to make such a
financial commitment? Not to mention, the monies are all paid out before the
child is even legally adopted!

In addition, with the ever increasing timeframes in adoption, many families have to
pay these fees more than once, as the data only remain in the system for a
limited amount of time! So consider the fact that you aren't raising these fees
once per adoption, but twice!

I strongly recommend that you reconsider the idea of raising the fees that adoptive
parents must pay in order to build a family. It's already a financial hardship on
many families and why would you want to be responsible for making it worse?

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by J. Stoll
